subject: FORWARD rules for public network
commit_message:
FORWARD rules for public network

CentOS7 comes with pre-defined REJECT rule in FORWARD chain
that doesn't allow to access external networks from public
network.

When deploying ISO with virtualbox scripts slave nodes are trying
to connect to external networks via public net, with default
gateway on master node. However, they can't establish a connection
because there is no explicit rule in FORWARD chain to allow it,
so they are rejected.

This commit adds rules to allow connection to ext networks in
that usecase.

Compatible with CentOS6 & CentOS7 master node.

Blueprint: master-on-centos7

[Verify] Fixing issue with create_isolated_networks = False

If you take a look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/229623/ and the
corresponding test run [1], you will see that 70 tempest tests failed.
It is because the create_isolated_networks flag is set to False. The
wrong option value was introduced by the mentioned patch. We don't
need to set the value for the option because we have the corresponding
Tempest context that uses the following logic:

    if the cloud doesn't have any shared networks, the default behavior
    defined in Tempest will be used and Tempest itself will manage network
    resources, i.e Tempest will create networks, subnets, routers, etc;

    if the cloud has some shared networks, we will create our own shared
    network and specify its name in the Tempest config file to avoid the
    "Multiple possible networks found." error;

    if user configures the fixed_network_name option in the tempest.conf
    file manually, then we don't need to do anything.

So we should remove create_isolated_networks = False from the config.ini
file to fix the issue.

Also we should use use_dynamic_credentials = True instead of allow_tenant_
isolation = True because this option is deprecated [2].

Add reno for release notes management

This cycle, to address these problems for our ever-growing set of

handling release notes as files in-tree, to allow us to simply and
continuously build the release notes for stable branch point releases
and milestones on the master branch. The idea is to use small YAML
files, usually one per note or patch, to avoid merge conflicts on
backports and then to compile those files in a deterministic way
into a more readable document for readers. Files containing release

Improve metadata update operations

Currently our metadata operations in the DB and the API are less than
optimal, main issues are:

- To update metadata first we get all metadata in the API and add
  requested update metadata, then on the DB we retrieve each of the
  metadata keys and update one by one contents.

  metadata contents and for those that are not in the new metadata we
  retrieve the contents from the DB (again) and delete the entry.

This patch changes this so we no longer retrieve metadata in the API,
deletion does not retrieve any metadata from the DB and just makes 1
deletion request to the DB, and for changes we retrieve metadata once

Add useful 'time_it' decorator

Create a helpful decorator that can be attached to functions
or methods to show how long they take to run; internally it
uses a stop watch and provided logger to log with (and an

An example:

>>> from oslo_utils import timeutils
>>> import logging
>>> import time

subject: Add identity v3 API filtering to users and projects tables
commit_message:
Add identity v3 API filtering to users and projects tables

This adds API filtering to the Users and Projects tables when
using the identity v3 API. The new table_row_limit setting from
HORIZON_CONFIG is used as the maximum number of rows to display
in the table. If more than the max number are returned then the
data is truncated and a warning message is displayed telling the
user to use a filter to narrow down the results.

Experiments have shown that the Users page takes about 20 seconds
to load when there are 1049 users. Certainly this number will
depend on many variables, but of that 20 seconds only 0.37 seconds
is spent making the request to obtain the data. The 0.37 seconds
was obtained by using curl to make the request to list the users.
So the vast majority of the time seems to be spent rendering the
page. The default row rendering limit of 500 was chosen based on
these results with the assumptions that loading the page with 500
users would take roughly 10 seconds and that showing any more than
500 of anything on a page is not very useful. These assumptions are
of course open to debate.

It seems at the moment that user email and project description
fields are not filterable in identity v3, so the only field
that can currently be filtered on these tables is the name.

This patch also includes some general improvements to the API
filtering support in horizon and fixes an issue that will occur
if API filtering is used on a table with inline editing.

Add second-level hash for TLS support. If user mixing this hash into his
astute.yaml, values from it will be taken to TLS-related tasks instead

use_ssl:
  horizon: true
  horizon_public: true
  horizon_public_hostname: horizon.fuel.local
  horizon_public_usercert: true
  horizon_public_certdata: KeyPairStoredHere

  keystone: true
  keystone_public: true
  keystone_public_ip: <ip of external keystone>
  ...
  keystone_internal: true
  ...
  keystone_admin: true
  ...

  glance: true
  glance_public: true
  ...
